org.tantalum
Class Task

java.lang.Object
  org.tantalum.Task
All Implemented Interfaces:
Workable
Direct Known Subclasses:
HttpGetter, StaticCache.GetLocalTask, StaticCache.PutLocalTask, StaticWebCache.GetAnywhereTask, StaticWebCache.GetWebTask, UITask
public abstract class Task
extends java.lang.Object
implements Workable

A Task is the base unit of work in the Tantalum toolset. Any piece of code which runs in response to an event and does not explicitly need to be run on the user interface (UI) thread is usually implemented in an extension of Task.doInBackground(). It will automatically be executed on a background worker thread once fork() has been called.

Author:
phou

MAX_TIMEOUT

public static final int MAX_TIMEOUT

Constructor Detail

Task

public Task()
Create a Task with input value of null Use this constructor if your Task does not accept an input value, otherwise use the Task(Object) constructor.

Task

public Task(java.lang.Object in)
Create a Task with the specified input value. The default action is for the output value to be the same as the input value, however many Tasks will return their own value.

in -

notifyTaskForked

public void notifyTaskForked()
                      throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Check status of the object to ensure it can be queued at this time (it is not already queued and running)

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the task is currently queued or currently running

getValue

public final java.lang.Object getValue()
Get the current input or result value of this Task without forcing execution. If the task has not yet been executed, this will be the input value. If the task has been executed, this will be the return value.

Returns:

get

public final java.lang.Object get()
                           throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                  ExecutionException,
                                  CancellationException,
                                  TimeoutException
Execute synchronously if needed and return the resulting value. This is similar to join() with a very long timeout. Note that a MAX_TIMEOUT of 2 minutes is enforced.

Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException
ExecutionException
CancellationException
TimeoutException

set

public final void set(java.lang.Object value)
Override the current value of the task with a new value Note that this is not used in normal operations. Usually you set the value when creating the task, or pass in the value as an argument from the previous Task in a chain. It can be useful to update a Task not yet forked, or to override the normal result of a Task. Because you face a race condition when setting the value on Task which is currently forked or already running, you will receive an IllegalStateException. Only use this method before forking and after execution has completed.

Parameters:
value -

setValue

public final java.lang.Object setValue(java.lang.Object value)
Set the return value of this task during or at the end of execution. Note that although you can use this to set or override the initial input value of a task before fork()ing it, it is more clear and preferred to use the Task(Object) constructor to set the input value.

Parameters:
value -
Returns:

fork

public final Task fork()
Execute this task asynchronously on a Worker thread as soon as possible. This will queue the Task with Worker.NORMAL_PRIORITY

Returns:

join

public final java.lang.Object join(long timeout)
                            throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                   CancellationException,
                                   ExecutionException,
                                   TimeoutException
Wait for a maximum of timeout milliseconds for the Task to run and return it's evaluation value, otherwise throw a TimeoutExeception. Similar to get(), except the total wait() time if the AsyncTask has not completed is explicitly limited to prevent long delays. Never call join() from the UI thread with a timeout greater than 100ms. This is still bad design and better handled with a chained Task or UITask. You will receive a debug warning, but are not prevented from making longer join() calls from the user interface Thread.

Parameters:
timeout - in milliseconds
Returns:
final evaluation result of the Task
Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException - - task was running when it was explicitly canceled by another thread
CancellationException - - task was explicitly canceled by another thread
ExecutionException - - an uncaught exception was thrown
TimeoutException - - UITask failed to complete within timeout milliseconds

joinUI

public final java.lang.Object joinUI(long timeout)
                              throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                     CancellationException,
                                     ExecutionException,
                                     TimeoutException
Wait for a maximum of timeout milliseconds for the UITask to complete if needed and then also complete the followup action on the user interface thread. You will receive a debug time warning if you are currently on the UI thread and the timeout value is greater than 100ms.

Parameters:
timeout - in milliseconds
Returns:
final evaluation result of the Task
Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException - - task was running when it was explicitly canceled by another thread
CancellationException - - task was explicitly canceled by another thread
ExecutionException - - an uncaught exception was thrown
TimeoutException - - UITask failed to complete within timeout milliseconds

setStatus

public final void setStatus(int status)
Change the status You can only change status CANCELED or EXCEPTION to the READY state to explicitly indicate you are going to re-use this Task. Note that Task re-use is generally not advised, but can be valid if you have a special need such as performance when re-creating the Task is particularly expensive.

Parameters:
status -

chain

public final Task chain(Task nextTask)
Add a Task (or UITAsk, etc) which will run immediately after the present Task and on the same Worker thread. The output result of the present task is fed as the input to doInBackground() on the nextTask, so any processing changes can propagated forward if the nextTask is so designed. This Task behavior may thus be slightly different from the first Task in the chain, which by default receives "null" as the input argument unless setValue() is called before fork()ing the first task in the chain.

Parameters:
nextTask -
Returns:
nextTask

You can call this as the return statement of your overriding method once you have set the result

Specified by:
exec in interface Workable
Returns:

cancel

public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning)
Cancel execution if possible. This is called on the Worker thread Do not override this unless you also call super.cancel(boolean). Override onCanceled() is the normal notification location, and is called from the UI thread with Task state updates handled for you.

Parameters:
mayInterruptIfRunning - (not yet supported)
Returns:

Check of the task has been had cancel() called or has thrown an uncaught exception while executing.

Returns:
